section.p:
crodh blàth warm cattle –
Bha Calum sgìth a’ coiseachd air a’ mhonadh, ach mu dheireadh ràinig e mullach na beinne. [...] Bha latha briagha ann agus bha a’ ghrian a’ deàrrsadh. [...] Bha an crodh blàth le teas na gréine agus bha iad ’nan seasamh anns na lochan beaga a bha an siud ’s an seo air feadh a’ mhonaidh.
Malcolm was tired walking on the moor, but at last he reached the top of the mountain. [...] It was a beautiful day and the sun was shining. [...] The cattle were warm with the heat of the sun and they were standing in the little lakes which were here and there throughout the moor. td. 146

biadh ... crodh ... feeds cattle –
Dh’éirich athair na cloinne agus màthair na cloinne aig sia uairean sa’ mhadainn. Thòisich am màthair air obair an taighe aig fichead mionaid an déidh sia, agus chaidh an athair a mach a bhiadhadh a’ chrùidh aig leth-uair an déidh sia.
The children’s father and mother rose at six o’ clock in the morning. Their mother started on the housework at twenty minutes past six, and their father went out to feed the cattle at half past six. td. 183

cuir ... crodh ... ... puts cattle ... –
An do chuir Calum an crodh do’n mhonadh? Chuir.
Did Malcolm put the cattle to the moor? Yes, he did. td. 47

faic ... crodh ... sees cattle –
Chunnaic mi caoraich agus crodh anns a’ mhonadh.
I saw sheep and cattle on the moor. td. 21
